stream_context.summary: Kaze models and lays out a new craft-themed course, debates how to fake normal-mapped styrofoam on N64 hardware, and sketches the six mission structures (crayon escort, paper-plane ride, pyramid red coins, 8-bit pipe, cave, final biome). He also prototypes cardboard NPC doodles, swaps mushrooms for paper-plate umbrellas, adds popsicle-stick bridges, and brainstorms cardboard enemies (saws, scissors, womps). By stream’s end he decides to drop the planned ice section in favor of a castle biome.
level: Craft World (unnamed course in Return to Yoshi’s Island)

development_findings.summary: Styrofoam ‘mountains’ use a CPU-generated texture that multiplies pre-baked normal vectors by the camera vector to fake dynamic reflection; Kaze isn’t sure whether to call it a normal, bump, or height map.
development_findings.quote: The whole point of this is to be able to have the lighting bounce off it dynamically so it fits what the camera would see.

development_findings.summary: He added crayons at the start that act as wooden blocks; a tilting popsicle-stick bridge will lead to a Luigi doodle requesting a yellow crayon for an escort mission.
Red coins were moved inside a pyramid reached via paper springs, consolidating two stars’ worth of content.
A paper-plane star will sling Mario on a rubber-band path, revealing an 8-bit pipe for another mission.
development_findings.quote: The paper plane is gonna just go crazy and shoom shoom shoom until you land back here.

development_findings.summary: He plans a rolling crayon log section inside a cardboard trough, inspired by SM64 rolling logs, to increase mechanical variety.
CPU normal-map technique requires a separate texture per orientation; adding beveled edges would double textures from 4 to 8 and raise memory costs.
development_findings.quote: Meaning if you want something that's not a cube, I need to add the new rotation to it.

development_findings.summary: N64 emulators do not yet support new F3DEX3 microcode features he’s using, limiting public testing.
development_findings.quote: The problem with F3DEX3 stuff is that emulators haven't gotten there yet.

development_findings.summary: He implemented flat-cardboard NPCs by weight-painting doodle textures to a low-poly mesh so they can flop or wave slightly.
development_findings.quote: This could be a talking animation—someone bending the cardboard.

development_findings.summary: After struggling with plausible craft-material ice, he decides to replace the planned ice biome with a cardboard castle area.
Potential cardboard enemies listed: scissors, saw blades, spindle/grindles in pyramids, cardboard thwomps/womps/bombs; chain chomp idea rejected.

context_findings.summary: Kaze openly hates traditional drawing and the famous Blender ‘donut tutorial,’ preferring self-directed reading of documentation.
context_findings.quote: I'm the number one donut tutorial hater.

context_findings.summary: He jokes about mixed community feedback: chat dislikes styrofoam color and mushroom models, prompting live changes.
context_findings.quote: Any more complaints about the styrofoam before I move on?

context_findings.summary: He relies heavily on texture-hunting during streams and pokes fun at how often sessions ‘devolve into looking for textures.’
context_findings.quote: Am I doomed to roam this earth just looking for textures all my life?

context_findings.summary: Financially sustains work via donations; celebrates a $50 tip as ‘10 burgers.’
Shows concern for performance budgets: notes a 600-triangle styrofoam model is ‘holy shit’ high and worries about billboard costs.
Personal dynamic: light banter with spouse Zeina (e.g., discovering Mario Kart Wii doesn’t allow two-player Grand Prix) reflects casual, collaborative home environment.

biobak.summary: Currently helping Kaze rework some existing levels rather than building this one.
biobak.quote: Biobak is helping me rework some of my levels.

badub.summary: Composing most of the game’s soundtrack and takes live requests during streams.
badub.quote: Badub is making most of the music.

zeina.summary: Appears in chat, offers opinions, and was involved in earlier testing sessions (e.g., Mario Kart Wii); no animation tasks mentioned this stream.

key_stories.title: Styrofoam Shading Debate
key_stories.summary: Kaze tries to sell the audience on his ‘styrofoam mountain’ material but chat insists the lighting is wrong. He realizes he’s mixing up normal, bump, and height-map concepts.
key_stories.challenge: Make styrofoam look reflective and 3-D without costly geometry.
key_stories.process: Implemented a CPU-generated texture multiplying normals by camera vector; debated math with chat and considered switching to light-direction basis.
key_stories.outcome: Keeps current method but notes need to add rotation, bevels, and possibly recolor to satisfy feedback.
key_stories.key_quote: It looks nice, but it's incorrect.

key_stories.title: Luigi’s Yellow Crayon Escort
key_stories.summary: Designing the first star: a depressed cardboard Luigi asks Mario to fetch a yellow crayon across enemy-filled dunes.
key_stories.challenge: Create a mission that ties level’s craft theme to gameplay.
key_stories.process: Placed tilting popsicle bridge, enemy zone, pickup object, and doodle NPC; sourced chat-made Luigi art and rigged it as flat mesh.
key_stories.outcome: Mission layout finalized; requires enemy and carry-object code.
key_stories.key_quote: I need a yellow crayon to finish my star.

key_stories.title: Mushroom Makeover
key_stories.summary: Chat criticizes rough low-res mushroom props; Kaze searches reference images live, settling on paper-plate umbrella mushrooms with decal dots.
key_stories.challenge: Mushroom models looked ‘too low-res’ and off-theme.
key_stories.process: Scrolled texture sites, tested cloth wrinkles and multi-texturing, switched stem to popsicle stick and cap to red plate with decals.
key_stories.outcome: New mushrooms approved by chat, showing iterative community influence.

open_questions.topic: Technical details of CPU-driven normal mapping
open_questions.context: He claims to compute textures on CPU for each orientation but did not explain memory costs or runtime generation.
questions: How exactly are the per-orientation textures generated and stored?
What is the frame-time cost on real N64 hardware?
Could this technique scale to larger objects or many materials?

open_questions.context: Current builds won’t run on most emulators, limiting tester pool.
questions: Which features are missing in common emulators?
Is there a fallback microcode path for players?
How will this affect release and speedrunning scenes?

open_questions.context: Ice area scrapped mid-stream; castle or volcano alternatives floated.
questions: What theme replaces the ice section definitively?
How will that choice influence enemy and mechanic selection?
Does it affect narrative or overworld flow?

open_questions.context: List of concepts (saw blades, scissors, cardboard womps) exists but none are prototyped.
questions: Which enemies are confirmed for this course?
Who will model, animate, and code them?
What unique behaviors differentiate them from vanilla SM64 counterparts?

open_questions.context: Kaze hints overworld will ‘tie everything together’ and should be done later.
questions: What is the envisioned overworld structure and aesthetic?
How will course entrances integrate craft motif?
What technical constraints (memory, microcode) govern overworld size?
